maml:description.maml:para: Connect to active directory.
Connect to active directory.

maml:Description.maml:para: A remote domain controller to attempt to bind to for this connection. If not defined then the current joined domain will be used with the closest domain controller found.
Alternate credentials to use for the connection.
A remote domain controller to attempt to bind to for this connection. If not defined then the current joined domain will be used with the closest domain controller found.
Alternate credentials to use for the connection.

dev:remarks.maml:para: PS> $a = Connect-ActiveDirectory -Creds $cred -ComputerName 10.10.10.10 PS> $a.Path = 'LDAP://10.10.10.10/RootDSE' PS> $a.namingContexts
Using alternate credentials connect to 10.10.10.10 then browse to the RootDSE and use it to list all the available AD partitions

PS> $a = Connect-ActiveDirectory -Creds $cred -ComputerName 10.10.10.10 PS> $a.Path = 'LDAP://10.10.10.10/RootDSE' PS> $Script:CurrentDomains = Connect-ActiveDirectory -ADContextType:Domain -Creds $cred -Computer 10.10.10.10 PS> $DCs = $Script:CurrentDomains.DomainControllers PS> ForEach($partition in ($a.namingContexts)) { PS> Write-Host -ForegroundColor:Magenta "Partition: $($partition)" PS> Foreach ($DC in $DCs) { PS> $Script:CurrentDomainControllerMetadata = $DC.GetReplicationMetadata($partition) PS> $dsaSignature = $Script:CurrentDomainControllerMetadata.Item("dsaSignature") PS> Write-Host -ForegroundColor:DarkMagenta " Server = $($DC) --- Backed up $($dsaSignature.LastOriginatingChangeTime.DateTime)`n" PS> } PS> }

Using alternate credentials connect to 10.10.10.10 then enumerate the partitions in the domain as well as the DCs. Then generate a report of the last backup time being reported on each DC for each partition.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Retrieve the first GPO with all properties and convert/display the user client side extensions to a readable format.

maml:description.maml:para: Translates Active Directory names between various formats.

Translates Active Directory names between various formats using the NameTranslate COM object. Before names can be translated, the NameTranslate object must first be initialized. The default initialization type is 'GC' (see the -InitType parameter). You can use the -Credential parameter to initialize the NameTranslate object using specific credentials.

maml:Description.maml:para: The output name type, which must be one of the following: 1779 RFC 1779; e.g., 'CN=Phineas Flynn,OU=Engineers,DC=fabrikam,DC=com' DN short for 'distinguished name'; same as 1779 canonical canonical name; e.g., 'fabrikam.com/Engineers/Phineas Flynn' NT4 domain\username; e.g., 'fabrikam\pflynn' display display name domainSimple simple domain name format enterpriseSimple simple enterprise name format GUID GUID; e.g., '{95ee9fff-3436-11d1-b2b0-d15ae3ac8436}' UPN user principal name; e.g., 'pflynn@fabrikam.com' canonicalEx extended canonical name format SPN service principal name format
The name to translate. This parameter does not support wildcards.

The input name type. Possible values are the same as -OutputType, with the following additions: unknown unknown name format; the system will estimate the format SIDorSIDhistory SDDL string for the SID or one from the object's SID history The default value for this parameter is 'unknown'.

The type of initialization to be performed, which must be one of the following: domain Bind to the domain specified by the -InitName parameter server Bind to the server specified by the -InitName parameter GC Locate and bind to a global catalog The default value for this parameter is 'GC'. When -InitType is not 'GC', you must also specify the -InitName parameter.
When -InitType is 'domain' or 'server', this parameter specifies which domain or server to bind to. This parameter is ignored if -InitType is 'GC'.

This parameter specifies whether to chase referrals. (When a server determines that other servers hold relevant data, in part or as a whole, it may refer the client to another server to obtain the result. Referral chasing is the action taken by a client to contact the referred-to server to continue the directory search.)
Uses the specified credentials when initializing the NameTranslate object.

The output name type, which must be one of the following: 1779 RFC 1779; e.g., 'CN=Phineas Flynn,OU=Engineers,DC=fabrikam,DC=com' DN short for 'distinguished name'; same as 1779 canonical canonical name; e.g., 'fabrikam.com/Engineers/Phineas Flynn' NT4 domain\username; e.g., 'fabrikam\pflynn' display display name domainSimple simple domain name format enterpriseSimple simple enterprise name format GUID GUID; e.g., '{95ee9fff-3436-11d1-b2b0-d15ae3ac8436}' UPN user principal name; e.g., 'pflynn@fabrikam.com' canonicalEx extended canonical name format SPN service principal name format
The name to translate. This parameter does not support wildcards.

The input name type. Possible values are the same as -OutputType, with the following additions: unknown unknown name format; the system will estimate the format SIDorSIDhistory SDDL string for the SID or one from the object's SID history The default value for this parameter is 'unknown'.

The type of initialization to be performed, which must be one of the following: domain Bind to the domain specified by the -InitName parameter server Bind to the server specified by the -InitName parameter GC Locate and bind to a global catalog The default value for this parameter is 'GC'. When -InitType is not 'GC', you must also specify the -InitName parameter.
When -InitType is 'domain' or 'server', this parameter specifies which domain or server to bind to. This parameter is ignored if -InitType is 'GC'.

This parameter specifies whether to chase referrals. (When a server determines that other servers hold relevant data, in part or as a whole, it may refer the client to another server to obtain the result. Referral chasing is the action taken by a client to contact the referred-to server to continue the directory search.)
Uses the specified credentials when initializing the NameTranslate object.

maml:alert.maml:para: Written by Bill Stewart (bstewart@iname.com) PowerShell wrapper script for the NameTranslate COM object. http://windowsitpro.com/active-directory/translating-active-directory-object-names-between-formats

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command outputs the specified domain\username as a distinguished name.
PS C:\> Convert-DSName canonical 'CN=Phineas Flynn,OU=Engineers,DC=fabrikam,DC=com' This command outputs the specified DN as a canonical name.
PS C:\> Convert-DSName dn fabrikam\pflynn -InitType server -InitName dc1 This command uses the server dc1 to translate the specified name.
PS C:\> Convert-DSName display fabrikam\pflynn -InitType domain -InitName fabrikam This command uses the fabrikam domain to translate the specified name.
PS C:\> Convert-DSName dn 'fabrikam.com/Engineers/Phineas Flynn' -Credential (Get-Credential) Prompts for credentials, then uses those credentials to translate the specified name.
PS C:\> Get-Content DNs.txt | Convert-DSName -OutputType display -InputType dn Outputs the display names for each of the distinguished names in the file DNs.txt.

maml:description.maml:para: Escapes Active Directory special characters from a string.
There are special characters in Active Directory queries/searches. This function escapes them so they aren't treated as AD commands/characters.

maml:Description.maml:para: The input string with any Active Directory-sensitive characters escaped.
The input string with any Active Directory-sensitive characters escaped.

I have AD special characters \28I think\29.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves the plaintext password and other information for accounts pushed through Group Policy Preferences.
Get-DSGPOPassword searches a domain controller for groups.xml, scheduledtasks.xml, services.xml and datasources.xml and returns plaintext passwords.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specify the domain controller to search for. Default's to the users current domain
Specify the domain controller to search for. Default's to the users current domain

maml:alert.maml:para: Original function from PowerSploit: Get-DSGPOPassword Author: Chris Campbell (@obscuresec) License: BSD 3-Clause Required Dependencies: None Optional Dependencies: None

maml:description.maml:para: Get AD objects of any kind.
Get AD objects of any kind. Used by most other functions for AD retrieval.

maml:Description.maml:para: Object to retreive. Accepts distinguishedname, GUID, and samAccountName.
Domain controller to use for this search.
Credentials to use for connection to AD.
Limits items retrieved. If set to 0 then there is no limit.
Root of search.
Custom LDAP filters for searches. By default these are joined by logical AND.
In addition to custom filters use this as an immutable filter for searches.
Properties to include in output. Is not used if ResultsAs is set to directoryentry.
Items returned per page.
Scope of a search as either a base, one-level, or subtree search, default is subtree.
Specifies the available options for examining security information of a directory object.
Whether the search should also return deleted objects that match the search filter.
Use logical OR instead of AND in custom LDAP filtering
Account was modified after this time
Account was modified before this time
Account was created after this time
Account was created before this time
Output will automatically join the attributes unless this switch is set.
Include all properties for an object.
Include unset (null) properties as defined in the schema (with or without values). This overrides the Properties parameter and can be extremely verbose.
Expands the UAC attribute into readable format. Only effective if the ResultsAs parameter is psobject
Skip attempts to convert known property types but still returns a psobject.
How the results are returned. psobject (which includes interpretted properties), directoryentry, or searcher. Default is psobject.
Escapes special characters in the filter ()/\*`0

maml:alert.maml:para: It is best to pipe users in via get-dsuser or get-dscomputer where possible. This function is missing -Whatif implementation at this time.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Removes jdoe to the 'Sales Team' group without prompting for confirmation.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets properties of an AD object
Sets properties of an AD object. You can set a single property or pass in a hashtable of property/value pairs to be updated.

maml:Description.maml:para: Domain controller to use.
Credentials to use for connection to AD.
A hash of properties to update.
Force update of the property without prompting.
Object to update. Accepts DN, GUID, and name formats.
